title: Dremel / Ozito Flexi Attachment [Vertically Mounted] Sander/Grinder

description.text:
This is a sanding/grinding table add-on with the Flexi attachment mounted vertically for better access to the sanding drum.

If you have the Dremel Flexi attachment, then it comes with a plastic clamp to suspend the tool to use the Flexi attachment. The Black clamp, in the 2nd picture is the one that comes with the attachment.

This item is designed as a universal clamp fitting, specifically for this Black clamp. And this is an add-on for the Flexi Tool attachment to be used with this clamp.

Printer:

Geeetech Full Metal Aluminum

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25 - 30%

Notes:

This Thingi has been designed in 3 pieces to snap fit together to avoid, as much as possible, the use of any supports. Only the bbSandingBoxV2-2.stl needs supports. The other 2 parts don't need any support.

Infill of 25 to 30% will give it more strength.

Assembly

Some filing and tidying is needed to make the parts fit together.

Assemble them in this order:
Snap the bbUniversalDremelClampHex into the (grey) base. Insert the Flexi tool and adjust its height as needed. Tighten it in place with a screw+nut.
Finally snap in the Sanding table. Just be careful with this part as the feet may snap off. For a more permanent solution, the table can be glued down to the long grey piece. But don't glue the (a) bbSandingBaseV2Hex to the (b) bbUniversalDremelClampHex as this item (b) will be reused in other projects I have in mind since it custom fits the Black clamp which conveniently fixes to any table.
This was designed in Sketchup 2016 with the idea of making the clamp fitting usable in other projects.. The Sketchup files are included for editing / customisation.

author: snowman8996

description.text: I made four of these music boxes as christmas gifts to my family. The PDF pattern was generated with a Processing script, which I wrote. I've included the script for reference, although you only need the PDF to produce copies of the box. Each box is laser cut from a single piece of 12x12 plywood. Here's a video of my daughter on Christmas: http://youtu.be/n9I88Lt0zUw The lid of the box contains an inlaid Hilbert curve, a kind of space-filling fractal. A more detailed Hilbert curve is etched into the bottom of the box. The sides of the box contain inlays or holes in the shape of the letter J, which is the first initial of each of my four family members. The pieces of the box fit together like a puzzle. Each side contains a single letter J, which I dyed different colors, using food coloring. These could also have been left as holes, to make the box louder. The crank hole is designed for a very common type of hand-cranked movement, of which Kikkerland is one manufacturer.

The pattern is designed for 12 x 12 x 1/4 inch wood.  I used pine plywood from a local hobby shop.  If you use thinner plywood, you'll need to tweak the puzzles edges of the pattern for the thinner wood.  
Load the pattern into Corel draw, or whatever you use to print to your laser cutter.  You will need to change all the lines to hairlines to make them cut.  Everything in the pattern is a line, except the red area, which is etched, so it's safe to do a "select all" and then select hairline thickness.
If you are using a different music box movement, or no movement, you should adjust or remove the side hole that is intended for the knob/key.  You can replace the J letters with a different letter, or design of your choice.  The Js I used come from the Zapf Chancery font.
The pattern is 10.5 x 10.75, filling most of a 12x12 piece of wood.  If you are cutting two boxes on a 12 x 24 piece of wood, I suggest cutting the wood in half first, to ease warping. This will improve the accuracy of the laser.
After cutting the pieces, I carefully removed the inlay piece from the top, and the J hole shapes, and set them aside.  All the remaining pieces (the top frame, the sides, and the bottom) I sanded and dyed with a cherry wood stain.
The inlay piece is very fragile and should be handled (and sanded) carefully - it is a single curve, whose two halves, and 4 quadrants are connected with a single piece (like the brain's corpus callosum).  Those connective pieces can receive a lot of stress, and fracture if you aren't careful.  For my box, I left the inlay piece it's natural color, to contrast with the darker stain.  I glued it in offset by a few millimeters, which gives the edges of the Hilbert curve a nice shadow.
I dyed each of the J holes a different light color (yellow, red, green, purple) by submerging in a food coloring / water solution for a minute.  You could also leave the J holes out (which will make the music louder), or put them inside the box as charms.
I cut adhesive felt pieces for the interior of the bottom and sides, leaving a square hole for the music box movement.  The music box movement can be screwed down or hot glued in (I used small screws).

description.text:
Update 8/2/17: Thickened the parts for the shrouded setup in hopes of making it a little more robust. I have not printed the parts but they look okay in CAD. I also modified the hardware used on the thicker parts to take advantage of easier to find M4x50mm screws (per canadadry's feedback). Just sub in the (3) thickened parts as needed.

Update 4/21/16: Modified base option added that provides a slight tilt to the whole assembly as seen in the first pic.

I couldn't justify paying $60 for an off-the-shelf fume extractor so I designed this for use while soldering or dealing with other unwanted vapors. The fan is a standard 12V 120mm case fan and the filter is 130mm x 130mm x 10mm (link in parts section). It also employs an on/off switch and power jack.

There are a couple of configuration options:

  • The rear vent is optional; if you plan to install it, print out the base designed for the vent (base_for_vent.stl). If you think you might want to add the vent later, go ahead and print the base for the vent, it will be perfectly functional without the vent installed.
  • There is a flat front panel as well as a shrouded front panel.
  • There is an additional tilted base option available that will tilt the shroud at a 20 deg angle.

Additional Parts Needed
(1) 120mm 12V case fan
(1) 130mm x130mm x 10mm carbon filter (http://www.amazon.com/Carbon-Filter-Activated-Xytronic-Absorber/dp/B005C5HUI8 or equiv.)
(1) Rocker switch (Philmore p/n 30-16705 or equiv.)
(1) DC power jack 2.1mm x 5.5mm (Philmore p/n 247 or equiv.)
(1) 12V power adapter (http://www.amazon.com/KCRIUS-Power-Adapter-Supply-2-1mm/dp/B00KG3A25Y or equiv.) Note that the recommended adapter has a fairly short cord, if you need something longer feel free to substitute.
(4) M4 x 55mm socket head cap screws
(4) M4 nuts
(4) M4 washers (if not using rear vent)

Instructions

  1. Print the following parts:
    • Hood_A
    • Hood_B OR Hood_B_with_shroud
    • Base OR Base_for_Vent OR Tilted_Base_for_Vent
    • Rear_Vent (Optional)
  2. If using the rear vent, install the nuts into the reliefs in the back of the mounting tabs.
  3. Wire up the fan, switch and power jack.
  4. Secure the switch and power jack into the base.
  5. Run the screws through Hood_A, the base and the fan.

  6. a. If using the vent, install now and use embedded nuts to secure everything together.
    b. If not using the vent, install the washers and nuts directly onto the screws, securing everything together.

  7. Carefully clip Hood_B/Hood_B_with_Shroud to Hood_A.
  8. Install carbon filter in the cavity created by the two hood pieces.
  9. Breathe easy.

The French Hair Braider is an attachment for the Python Prosthetic hand by Aaron Brown of Axislab 3D which can be found here:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/python-utility-hand-alternative-assistive-device

A tool to help french braid hair. I made one to attach to the left hand and one to be attached to the right. The angle at which it is attaches to the Python Prosthetic is opposite for right and left hand for a more comfortable hand position while braiding. I have not 3D printed this design, but I have tested it using thick poster board

DIRECTIONS:
Labeling the openings A,B,C,D

Begin with a piece of hair in each A, C, and D
Then move the pieces of hair in the following method

D-->B
C-->D
A-->C
B-->A

Add hair to A and D
Repeat the above steps

description.text:
2.5"ø Mecanum Roller Wheel Design:
The rollers are male/female interference fit, no hardware required. There are (7) pairs of male/female rollers per wheel, total (4) wheel assembly will require (28) pairs.Roller pairs press together and bottom out leaving clearance on hub and spin freely. Wheel hub has right/left variations with a 0.50"ø hole in the center for custom hub (will post the hub I use for a nema 17 stepper soon). The hub's back face is 0.50" offset from the center line of the wheel and the overall width is ~1.30" with a rolling diameter of 2.50". Full STEP file assemblies are in the download section.

Regards,

Printer:

Geeetech i3-C

Notes:

I printed this in PLA with a touching bed support incline of 48° for the hubs and 14 male/female roller pairs with out raft or brim on glass (ext 215°c bed 60° with light adhesive spray).

Currently, I'm working on designing & building a fully 3D printed mecanum wheel robot as a test bed for learning stepper motors, controls, then ultimately wireless controls and operation with arduino platforms. This will be a work in progress for the next few months as I modify my requirements.

04/03/16: Added Nema17 wheel hub.

I have a job interview coming up in a few days and I can never find a tie clip when I need one. Instead of investing a over 10 dollars for something I'll probably loose, I instead spent about 20 minutes with tinkercad and came up with this.

title: Rigidbot 2 Highly effective part cooling fan duct

description.text:
This is a high efficiency fan duct upgrade for the stock part cooling fan on a Rigidbot 2. This fan duct attaches using all stock parts so no modifications or extra parts are required to install it on a Rigidbot 2 printer. For best results read the print settings carefully.

The clip on the fan snaps onto the front bearing mount easily but securely and is easy to remove if needed. The pictures show the orientation and sequence to attach the fan duct and install the stock fan.

The fan duct design directs a concentrated high flow moderate pressure stream of cool air across the tip of the nozzle parallel to the top surface of the part removing the heat quickly from the area. This results in a much more uniform cooling pattern and surface finish even across thin and small parts greatly reducing warping and curling. Bridging capabilities are enhanced and features on the far side of the nozzle are stabilized. It is a truly awesome sight to watch the printer effortlessly create bridge spans of at least 15 mm with no visible sag and horizontal overhangs of up to 5 mm that are flat by the third layer. I use this piece as a test piece. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1088310 I'm going to have to scale it up to test the limits of this fan duct.

The air stream passes below the heater block so as to not cause temperature fluctuations across the head. The duct will clear all parts of the printer and does not interfere with or touch the guide rods.

Since this is a precision fit part I highly recommend using calibrated filament. My filament calibration object of choice is found here as it calibrates for the average diameter of the filament being used and its thermal expansion and cooling properties: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1037301

To avoid melting the end of the installed duct it is recommended that the heater be pushed in nearly flush with the front of the heater block.

The STL file is Cura scaled and oriented for printing.

Printer:

Rigidbot 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

24%

Notes:

This part will need supports with an overhang angle between 60 and 45 and fairly dense in the range of 25 - 30%. I also recommend a brim of 7 - 10 lines to anchor it to the bed more securely especially for the fan bolt mount which is the only place the part itself touches the bed.

First layer is printed at 0.2mm and the rest are at 0.1mm. Use a 0.8 shell and 0.8 top and bottom thickness at these resolutions. Start with the bed at 60 C and turn it down to 45 on layer 4 (0.5mm high). The stock cooling fan comes on full at layer 5 and provide adequate cooling for the first print of this part. I used my first test prototype to cool my second and final print. You may want to print a second fan using the first one produced using the stock cooling duct.

As mentioned above use calibrated filament for best fit results.

Post print clean up

Remove the support material from the back of the duct and any strings inside the duct. you should not have any support material inside the duct itself.

comments.text: Wow!  Successfully spanned 95 mm in the direction of air flow and on layer 3 everything was flat and filled in.  Less than 0.3mm of sag.  Running at 0.1mm layer thickness.
comments.author: JP1

title: Spacers For InMoov Simple Server Bed when using HK 15298B Servos

description.text:
I am building the InMoov Robot and when I tried to install the recommended servos I discovered the Simple Server Bed was not deep enough,. Rather then design a whole new servo bed part I created these spacers to use with the one provided. You can use all small ones but I also included a large one for the spots that have more room. Some places only the smaller one will work. Position so the square holes are over the screw holes. You will also need longer wood screws. I am using #6 5/8"

I also included the 123d design files in case you need to modify. One for the Simple Servo Bed would have made things a lot easier

print_settings.Notes:: 40% infill was just a guess for initial testing.  Might need more, won't know until its been in use for awhile.

description.text:
Simple 3 part leg set for increasing the stability of the Portabee-kit 3d printer. The standard printer has issues with possibly falling over when printing at height due to its "take-apart" design. Since i'm not trying to keep this portable and able to be stuffed into a laptop bag i'm adding these legs to help brace it.

Print 2 legs and 1 glue plate per side. This slides over the 6mm threaded rods inbetween the base and the Y-carraige mounting.

I tried the wide-base file on here, but that one raised the center of gravity even though it did widen the footprint. I looked at the piece that attached to the Y-carriage but decided i still needed the easy ability to remove that section at will.

4 extra 6mm nuts per set of legs will be required in addition to these files to install the legs as well as some filing to the bottoms to get everything sitting level.

I used a piece of smooth 6mm rod while gluing to ensure the holes lined up between the glue plate and the leg sections.

It is in 3 pieces due to the size restriction of the portabee build plate.

Printer:

Portabee-kit

No

No

.2

40%

40% infill was just a guess for initial testing. Might need more, won't know until its been in use for awhile.

title: Z Axis linear bearing spacer for Thing-O-Matic

description.text: This is an easy way to fit SW06UU linear bearings to the TOM Z axis and get rid of the not ideal bushings. This solved my problem with inconsistent movement of the Z axis and now it is moving much smoother and it became quieter.

Print 4 pieces, on for each of the bearings on Z axis. Put one circlip on each bearing and slide it in to the z stage. Then put the spacer on the linear bearing and put another circlip on top of the spacer. Make sure the spacer are on the outside (top/ bottom) of the Z stage. See picture. Repeat for the other 3 and you are done.
The hole ID is set to 8.3mm to compensate for shrinkage and OD is 22mm. Hight is for my bot and compensated for shrinkage 8.55mm.
These measurments are for ABS filament.

title: Universal Filament Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hello Everyone,

Today we wanted to share our universal filament holder with you all. Based on two cones, the Universal Filament Holder is auto-centering, and low friction. Included are the mounts for both a Kossel Pro, and LulzBot Taz 5 (20mm x 20mm extrusions) as well as the DXF file from the base of the arm, to allow you to create your own mount, and adapt it to your own 3D printer. (if you do this please link and give credit to the rest of the design, i.e. this page)

Check out Versus-PC.com for more designs

Printer:

LulzBot Taz 5 & Kossel Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

30%

Notes:

All of the parts have been designed to be easily printed without support, rotate them as necessary

The Stopper is pretty tight as is, but is designed to house an M3 nut and setscrew, to ensure stability during long prints.

The aluminum rod used is 9.6mm (3/8") , and should be easily found at any local hardware store.

author: jeremylee77

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58413

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58413

Using the following options:

elipseSize = [size * ratio,size,height]
initials = AT
letter_height = 1
height = 3

I need two cameras to capture depth perception when in FPV mode. This bracket holds two cameras and two transceivers and bolts onto the front of the quadcopter frame with three screws.

Once snapped into place, both cameras will look straight ahead without adjustment. The inter-pupillary distance of the mounted cameras is 31.8mm (similar to a cat or small simian) so your depth perception will be a bit more shallow relative to that of a normal human and it's naturally ideal for navigating jungle-like conditions. From our point of view, everything nearby does appear 'larger' and you may be able to leverage this to maneuver through tighter spaces more responsively.

Designed to be mounted onto the Mini Flame Wheel Quadcopter:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:34552

If you found this useful, please make sure you share a picture (it makes my day each time someone prints something I designed) and be sure to peruse my other submissions which are almost as varied as they are many:

http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

Enjoy!

Oh, and special thanks to Frida the cat for letting me put a pair of calipers right up to her eyeballs. Such a mellow ball of fuzz. (^.^)

title: FliteTest Baby Blender 3D Printed Landing Gear Mod

description.text:
This week I designed and built a set of 3D printed landing gear for my scratch built FliteTest Baby Blender Biplane. Checkout my full post over at BackyardRC.workpress.com:
http://backyardrc.wordpress.com/2013/09/03/flitetest-baby-blender-with-3d-printed-landing-gear and FliteTest's site for build instructions: http://www.flitetest.com/articles/baby-blender-2-draft Want one of your own Baby Blender landing gear set printed for you? Or another design on thingiverse?? Contract my printer with 3D Hubs and I'll print, pack, and ship you your part within a few days!! Check it out: http://www.3dhubs.com/harrisburg/hubs/mark If you like the gear you might also like the custom motor mount for the blender. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:139930

title: Star Wars Imperial Assault - card tray - Obsolete (improved version available)

description.text:
This version is obsolete, there is a new version available with improved lid, three designs, more storage space and better functionality. Please see my other designs.

Box with three sections: large cards, small cards and tokens. You want to play a skirmish game and have carefully selected your troops and agenda cards. You can bring this small box along and keep them safely stored.

Please notice the bottom of the card box.

Room for unsleeved or sleeved cards. You can stow away 2cm height worth of cards of each type (about 35 or so)

The lid has restraints so it won't open accidentally. There is also the option to secure the lid additionally with magnets. Holes for four 2,5 mm by 2,5 mm round magnets and four 2 mm x 2 mm x 1 mm square magnets are present.

title: Knight -Chevalier
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a sculptur made with Blender for to see how I could do finishing in 3D. I went through a lot of steps for to try to clean the mesh, but there is still a lot of work I think. But I don't have enough time and courage to go on. Feel free to give it a go!!
I have added the different elements in STL, if it can help someone. Also by the way, I'm printing since a few days ABS on an unclad sheet of FR4 epoxy glass with a heated bed built under a piece Vitroceram glass at only 100 degrees celsius and it's a wonder. I had no warp, and Abs sticks surprisingly just like on Kapton tape. After the print is finished, I can just remove the epoxy sheet and it cools down (it can go fast with a little blow) and the part just pops off by itself!
This print is 160mm large and quiet massive, but it just goes fine even though my raft is really small.(see pictures)

Download either size you like from the STL files. Resize if you wish. I used the 114mm with ABS.(It's big) Layer thickness of 0.5, infill of 20%, 2 extra shells, support. (I'm not sure it was really needed, but I wanted to try)
Once cleaned up and sanded(I didn't do that much because I was lazy), deep it in to acetone for a minute or more, depanding on the result. Be sure to do that with gloves and a very well ventilated area.
Let it dry for about an hour. It remains soft under pressure of nails for about 3/4 hours.
Then start your paint job! Normally I would do a coating with car filler, but once again I was lazy.
Have fun during Christmas vacation!

description.text: The LYMAN FILAMENT EXTRUDER V3 is a complete filament extruding assembly for extruding 3D printer filament. It extrudes and winds the filament onto a spool which it then ready for use. The BOM shows a cost figure of near $900. The extruder alone can be made for under $250. See the video on YouTube: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p_E7crY9wfg

This Thing has been a 6 month project.  The uploaded manual will give you the information on making your own.  I have included a cad dfx file for those who wish to improve, correct, add to or make for resale.  As there are many folks with more know how than me, any suggestion with documentation is welcomed.  Good luck, WORLD.

Dear Mr Lyman, I have successfully your extruder, it works like a charm. Thank you for the detailed and well made instructions, they were easy and clear to follow.
For non americans planning to make a Lyman Filament Extruder V3, I give you the following information: It is difficult to obtain the Heat bands and drive rollers at a reasonable price, I had to purchase mine on trip to the USA, so if you are building one beware. Furthermore, no matter how close the metric to standard conversions are, the parts will never fit if you are mixing the two systems, so be prepared to do a lot of cnc milling if you are trying to combine the Urethene drive rollers with metric ball bearings. But I am very happy with the product and highly suggest people try to make one. Thank you Mr Lyman!

comments.text: Hugh, there is something that I think you modified but didn't update in the build instructions. In the parts list and in the video there are LED's and resistors to make power lights. However the parts list also specifies SPST (Single Pull Single Throw) switches. The electrical wiring diagram also doesn't specify the LED's. In order to put a power light on an AC circuit, the switches need to be SPDT (Single Pull Double Throw). The LED and resistor have to be on a different parallel circuit connected to the same SPDT switch as the AC parts.
comments.author: mnutsch

comments.text: It's pole, not pull, and you can certainly use SPST switches with AC circuits. The lightswitches in your house are a prime example.
comments.author: mnutsch

comments.text: or you could use SPST switches and simply add an AC lamp.    using an AC lamp in-circuit with the actual electronics, you could in theory also use the device itself as the resistive load for the lamp.
comments.author: mnutsch

comments.text:
Nice work on this! I have a couple of questions. Is there any issue with the barrel/hopper getting too hot after extended running?
Also, does this do an acceptable job in final diameter control? The dimensions are one aspect but how does this filament react in a 3D printer?
comments.author: 1965mt

comments.text: The barrel is hot back to the flange connection.  The hopper does not get hot if you have the insulation block installed correctly.  The hopper is ABS.  The the tolerance of the filament diameter vary +/- 0.10 mm.  It reacts fine in my 3D printer, such as I have printed beautiful Aphrodite statues and dozens of good parts including 16 each 8" filament spools I use for winding filament on.  It takes from 5 t0 7 hours to fill an 8" spool depending on your pellets and I have filled over 30 spools. so you see there is no problem with extended running.
comments.author: 1965mt

comments.author: hlyman

comments.text: This looks like a compact version of the industrial extruders out there with the cool tray , take up wheel and winder steps. How are you managing speed at the take up reel without putting stress on the filament as it exits the hot end? Is it necessary? My understanding is thats why the water tray is so large on the industrial versions but I could be wrong.
comments.author: drandolph

comments.text: The water tray on pro extruders needs to be 10+ ft long because extrusion speed is much higher. You can't drop the average temperature of the polymer much in a 4" water bath when it is moving at 50feet/min.
comments.author: drandolph

comments.text: You should find the answer by reading the manual on LYMAN FILAMENT WINDUP SPOOL.  The drive shaft turns faster than the spool so it slips on the edge of the spool keeping a constant pressure so it can only wind the filament as it exits the puller rollers. There is no stress on the filament as the puller roller maintains a constant speed and grip the filament tightly. Have you read the manual?  I may need to add to the manual.  But you are right, it is a compact version of an industrial extruder. Thanks for your comment.
comments.author: drandolph

comments.text: Thanks for replying back. I haven been watching your work for awhile now and I have been really impressed. I've been using some of you parts to build a diameter logging device like your motor mounts and your recommendations for speed controllers. I was wondering if you saw a problem between the hot end and the water tank? I've always assumed that the filament coming out of the hotend varies in speed and if the drive shaft before the spooler was set to fast it would pull the filament and thin it out. Even if you got the motor in perfect sync if the filament speeds up or down slightly it seems like it would end up stretching or binding before the water tank. This is only a guess by me so I'm just curious if you have seen that as a problem or if it's all in my head? I noticed you are now working on a resizing dye and that might be what solves the problem I'm referring too. I've also been following this project and their way of handling the speed problem is with photosensors. http://www.soliforum.com/topic/2038/filament-winder/http://www.soliforum.com/topic...
comments.author: hlyman

comments.text: You are right, the filament varies in thickness as it exits the nozzle.  As the motors are in sync, M2 follows M1 this leads me to the fact that the pressure inside the nozzle is not constant. In Versions 1 & 2 I had the auger bit end about 1.5" from the brass nozzle, wherein in this one I have it between 1/4" to 1/2".  I will revise this today to see if that improves the tolerance. Also, I find that the distance the water jet is from nozzle can affect the tolerance.  Yesterday I extruded 500 feet with the jet at 4" from the nozzle and this improved the tolerance. Further I am changing the M2 motor pot on the Kangaroo from the mini on board one to a precision external 10 turn pot, for more accurate adjustment of M2 motor.  I have tried the resizing die and have not yet got it to work.  Thanks for your comments.

title: Misfit 180/Nighthawk Pro Dual Mounting Point HS1177 Camera Mount

description.text:
EDIT: A fully adjustable camera mount has now been uploaded too. You can run any camera angle now.

I remixed SYCO's HS1177 25 degree camera mount to fit a Pats MiniH Quad Misfit 180 and also a Nighthawk Pro (remove the original camera plate and screw down using the hole and slot in the front of the bottom plate)

There are two mounting holes in the bottom plate to allow for different camera positions.
Originally I wanted something that would stop the camera from rotating in an impact. (25 degrees wedge)
But upon testing, using 1.5mm hex bolts into the HS1177 proved sturdy enough to stop the camera moving.

So I added a lug on and a second hole to SYCO's design. (6mm distance from both hole centres)

title: Self-splicing group I intron from bacteriophage Twort bound to CYT18

description.text: This is a self-splicing group I intron. It can excise itself from its surrounding RNA and paste the surrounding pieces of RNA back together. The CYT18 protein binds to the surface of the group I intron to help stabilize its three dimensional structure within a cell.

This was printed on a MakerBot Replicator 2X.  You will need to create a custom profile that uses the old support structure and not the newer sparser supports.  
First select standard quality then create a custom profile.  Then edit the profile and look for "supportExcessive".  Set this value to "true" and then save the preset.  
The build time for Twort is around 20 hours at 150% scale with standard quality and "Excessive" support.

author: gibv2003

description.text:
Description

Front shock absorbers (dampers) for Daniel's awesome F1 car!

V2 Updated Design!

I have been trying to come up with a more functional alternative for the NinjaFlex dampers in my suspension design. (They just weren't soft enough)

As I was changing batteries in one of my kids toys I noticed the little conical springs inside the battery compartment and I knew I had the solution! I can now say that this design works FANTASTIC!

By adding a recessed area to the hubs I was able to fit a longer spring from an AAA battery terminal over the guide bushings and allow the full travel I was looking for. The new attached pictures show the unassembled view with the new spring, the battery terminals I used, and the suspension both uncompressed and compressed.

The springs I used were from these battery terminals:

Keystone Electronics 5204 Contacts; Battery Spring Contacts; Negative Spring Contact with Tab, AAA, N (5 pieces)

http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00LPP7NZ4

I also uploaded a video to YouTube demonstrating how it works. https://youtu.be/YGE2oiwUV90

And posted a driving demo with all 3 of my designs installed on the car: https://youtu.be/g154r7Dcjas

Front Suspension: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1455120

Rear Suspension: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1455132

Standard F1 Rubber Tire Adapters: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1337521

By adding small NinjaFlex dampers to the rigid frame of the F1 car I was able to reduce some of the bounce and vibration of the front of the vehicle as well as allow a small amount of body roll to aid in cornering.

The front upper and lower control arms have been modified to allow a sliding pivot to be attached to the wheel hubs. Next the wheel hubs themselves were shortened vertically to allow for the placement of NinjaFlex (or possibly other materials) flexible spacers to act as small shock absorbers.

I printed the spacers out of NinjaFlex using a single layer on all sides to make them as soft as possible. (.2mm layer height and .4mm nozzle) Thinner would be better if you have a smaller nozzle. The key is to make them as soft as possible.

Instructions:

Print the following:

1x Front_Upper_BOM_Suspension

1x Front_Lower_BOM_Suspension

2x Front_Wheel_Hub_Suspension (One needs to be mirrored for the opposite side of the car.)

4x OpenRC F1 Guide Bushing

2x Front_Rim_Narrow (If you aren't using the rubber tires/wheels)

2x Front_Wheel_Narrow (In NinjaFlex if you aren't using the rubber tires/wheels)

Assemble as normal replacing BOM parts. Thread a Guide Bushing on each new longer screw and thread it into the Front_Wheel_Hub on each side. The smaller side of each hub faces up and gets one of the suspension spacers between it and the Upper_BOM. Use the photo above to help with assembly if necessary.

I would welcome others to design a better/softer damper or experiment with other materials. Small springs would probably work very well as well but I wanted to keep with the 3d-printed concept. This is an excellent project and I'm proud to be able to contribute.

If anyone has problems being able to mirror the part "Front_Wheel_Hub_Suspension" I can mirror it and upload another .stl file, just let me know.

description.text:
After designing front suspension for Daniel's OpenRC F1 car I decided I had to come up with a way to make REAR suspension work. After several attempts I'm proud to say I've succeeded! Using the same battery terminal springs, "AA" this time, I was able to shoe-horn in a functional rear suspension system.

The file "Chassis Rear_Suspension" has been added to give the proper mounting holes and remove some of the original ones that were no longer needed.

I have uploaded a quick video demonstrating how it works: https://youtu.be/7EPDpDtVf3I

And a driving demo with all 3 of my designs installed on the car: https://youtu.be/g154r7Dcjas

Front Suspension: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1455120

Rear Suspension: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1455132

Standard F1 Rubber Tire Adapters: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1337521

Instructions:

Print all of the pieces the list below and assemble as shown in the pictures above, replacing the originals.

Left Axle Mount (Requires Support)

Right Axle Mount (Requires Support)

Pivot

Spring Holder

Bottom Plate

Pressure Plate

Right Axle Mount

Left Axle Mount (Print a Mirror the Right. If necessary I can upload one already mirrored.)

Chassis Rear_Suspension

Motor Cover Suspension

All parts were printed in PLA with 90% infill except the motor cover, which was printed at 15% infill.

DO NOT print the file "Rear Suspension Assembled". I posted it to help with assembly.

This system uses several of the following battery terminals for springs: Keystone 5220

Link: http://www.amazon.com/KEYSTONE-FEMALE-BATTERY-CONT...

I started with 3 of the springs (they slide into the part called "spring holder" and ended up using 4 of them for increased support. You could use anywhere between 2 and 5 of them depending on the weight of your car and how stiff you want the suspension.

Enjoy!

8/23/16 - Added rear chassis with original mounting holes as requested. (Chassis Rear_Suspension_With_Original_Holes.stl)

author: tommistheman

title: EPSP synthase - the target of Round-Up

description.text: This plant enzyme is part of the cellular machinery that synthesizes essential amino acids, which are building blocks of proteins and precursors to many of the chemical compounds that plants make. Round-up binds to this enzyme and prevents it from working - killing the plant. Round-Up resistant plants have a variant of this enzyme that prevents Round-Up from binding and allowing the plants to live, even if they are sprayed with this herbicide.

This was printed on a MakerBot Replicator 2X. You will need to create a custom profile that uses the old support structure and not the newer sparser supports.  
First select standard quality then create a custom profile. Then edit the profile and look for "supportExcessive". Set this value to "true" and then save the preset.  
This molecule was printed in three parts and is held together with magnets.

title: X- Axis Belt Mounting Bracket v2 (Cocoon Create, Wanhao Di3 v2, etc.)

description.text:
NOTE: I have uploaded new STL files that incorporate a clearance notch for the lower rod

This is an upgrade of my previous design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1445762), I wasn't happy that I still had to use the cable ties and standard spring-clip tensioner so I incorporated a ratcheting pulley tensioner into the design. I've done a few prints with it installed and it is holding tension fine. The tension is adjusted using a 6mm Hex key (it only tightens though, if you go too tight, just disassemble the tensioner and start again.
It is designed specifically for the stock GT2 belt (2mm pitch x 6mm wide).

I'm pretty happy with the design, the only thing I'd change is the tooth pitch of the ratchet mechanism, currently the 12 teeth give about 3.1mm of belt travel per click, If I can halve that by doubling the teeth I think it will make for finer tension adjustment but I'll need to see whether the ratchet will be strong enough with the smaller teeth.

comments.text: Would you share the original step files? I'd love to modify it to fit my Corexy carriage.
comments.author: the0ry

comments.text: Well i made this, but I had to sand down the bottom side as it was rubbing the bottom rod.  Nice design but could you increase the bottom clearance by like 1mm?
comments.author: Zigian

comments.text:
Thanks for trying it out and letting me know, I'm working on an update at present and will see what I can do.I have a few follow up questions for you if you don't mind.
Which printer did you install it on and what is the distance between the rods?
Was it just the bottom corner on the extruder side (for installation) or the whole bottom face that is too close?
Did you have any issues with belt tension and do you think it needs finer adjustment in the ratchet?
comments.author: Zigian

comments.text: It was on the Wanhao Di3.  It was the entire bottom face rubbing on the rod.  I basically just filed a channel to allow clearance.  It was maybe 1/2mm or so.  The ratchet adjustment seemed to be ok.  A bit finer would be good, but it seems to work well as is.
comments.author: PlasticCow

comments.text: Great idea. I've been modelling the full printer to use as a template for upgrades and already have my own bearing block models so it should be easy. I was considering releasing a version without the belt slider anyway for those that already had the block mod installed.
comments.author: Zigian

comments.text: Could it be possible to distribute the full printer CAD model? As you said, it is very useful to design upgrade parts. BTW, I'm currently in the process of creating a remix of your X-Axis Belt mounting Bracket because I though the ratchet idea was very clever. I'm designing my version with a 16 ratchet teeth instead of 12. I'll let you know the results. Also, the clearance we see on picture 2 and 3, is it necessary because it's not in your STL file. How big is this notch?
comments.author: PlasticCow

comments.text: thanks for alerting me to the discrepency between the stl model and the design depicted in the photos, I was wondering why people were having problems mounting it, helps if I upload the right stl files I guess. I've uploaded the newer hopefully correct models now so try downloading them and see if it's any better. BTW the clearance is 2mm deep with a 5mm lip.
comments.author: JF_Chabot

comments.text: Thanks for the link, I will take a look at it.
comments.author: PlasticCow

comments.text: I've posted a remix of your design. Just to let you know.
comments.author: JF_Chabot

comments.text: Cool.  Well I'll just hold off on my combination then. :D
comments.author: PlasticCow

comments.text: You might be waiting a week or two before i get around to it though. So feel free to design your own. Let me know if you do and i'll link it in the description. My x-bearings are rattling and i need to replace them. I'll do the block design at the same time once they arrive.
comments.author: Zigian

comments.text: Cool.  I'm not in any hurry.  When you design it, can you do a version with just 1 upper block instead of 2?  I'm waiting for long bearings as well and that's when I'd change it out. :D
comments.author: PlasticCow

comments.text:
yup needs finer adjustment. move the belt at the other end clamp by a tooth or 2 and you should hit the sweet spot. the ratchet has a resolution of about 3mm so also moving the belt in the fixed end clamp lets you get down to about 1mm.
Sounds like I do need to double the ratchet resolution, 3mm is just too coarse.

comments.text: Great Job cool....BUT WAY TOO TIGHT

description.text: This is an RNA molecule and it is called the hepatitis delta virus ribozyme. This RNA is part of the genetic material of the virus. It is a molecular scissors, capable of cutting itself from the surrounding viral RNA.  This particular model has made it almost all the way around the world and currently resides in Taiwan.

This was printed on a MakerBot Replicator 2X. You will need to create a custom profile that uses the old support structure and not the newer sparser supports.  
First select standard quality then create a custom profile. Then edit the profile and look for "supportExcessive". Set this value to "true" and then save the preset.  
This model took 35 hours to print and was done at max build size.

Fire stand for LG G3

Fancy stand for LG G3 with hole for QI charger (chinese 60mm).
It comes with 3 sizes of "water". From small to big, on pictures there is a middle one.
Parametric CAD files available at https://cad.onshape.com/documents/45dc19bdecad77aa89bd19aa/w/1e5fb4b566956b2521b97f6e

You will need

  • 1x M5x100 screw
  • 1-2x M5 16mm long nut
  • 11x M2x17 screw + nuts
  • 2x M5x16 flat head screws
  • epoxy glue (or some similar universal glue)
  • putty for plastic (optional)
  • sand paper (optional)
  • spray colors (optional)

Assembly instructions

When prindet you will need sand surface and also sand hole for QI charger. It is designet very tightly because no one charger is perfectly same.
Optionally if you want you can drill hole to top of water part and glue in one M5x16 nut.
Whole design is for PLA.

Quick assembly video: https://youtu.be/rkfwV1a1BfY

description.text:
This is a stabilizing Bi-pod designed to fit air rifle barrels less than 17mm in diameter.

Its made so that a bit of felt or tissue can be wrapped around the barrel before being clamped on to prevent scratching the barrel.

!!!You will need 2 M4 Butterfly nuts and Bolts to screw on!!!

This is my first design upload so please comment if there is any problems with the model.
Thank you for downloading and happy printing!

Printer:

Velleman K8200

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

15% hexagon

Notes:

This was done with a 0.5mm nozzle and cheap 3mm PLA. My 3D printer is probably not as good yours so it shouldn't be a problem reducing the resolution and increasing infill density.

Side note: buy good quality PLA!!! I have had all kinds of trouble printing with cheap PLA!

title: DailyEarring#94:Broken light bulb
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
-> Daily Earring prologue: thingiverse.com/thing:7120
I'm going to color this one with metal and glow-in-the-dark nail polish, stay tuned!

Printing the medium version worked fine (using low support angles/settings).
Standing: rough looking wire, smoother bulb and bottom
Laying: Warped bulb, rough bottom part, smoother wire, but support inside the bulb...
(see comparison on pictures) Printing smaller will work if the wire/holder is sized down a little.

comments.text: This earring is Amazing!
comments.author: benglish

comments.text: Thanks! i hope no one notices the fake threading :-)
comments.author: benglish

comments.text: It looks just fine to me.  I imagine you implemented reverse threading to keep people from accidentally installing this printed light-bulb in a real light-socket.
comments.author: Schorhr

comments.text: It's just a bunch of disks, not an actual threading :-)
comments.author: benglish

comments.text: No worries, my troubles went away once I checked the "unsolid model" box.  Now that I have one printed out, I see what you mean about the threading!
comments.author: Schorhr

comments.text: Heh. I was to lazzy to make a helix/threading or install a plugin on this laptop. Artistic freedom :-)
comments.author: benglish
